Secondary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: CareFusion Corp. agreed to pay the government $40.1 million to settle allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by paying kickbacks and promoting its products for uses that were not approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
Agency: Food and Drug Administration referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/carefusion-pay-government-401-million-resolve-allegations-include-more-11-million-kickbacks

Description: C.R. Bard Inc. agreed to pay the United States $48.26 million to resolve claims that it knowingly caused false claims to be submitted to the Medicare program for brachytherapy seeds used to treat prostate cancer in violation of the False Claims Act.

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/manhattan-us-attorney-settles-civil-fraud-claims-against-medical-device-distributor

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: CareFusion, a manufacturer of medical and surgical supplies and medical devices, agreed to pay $40.1 million to settle multistate litigation alleging unlawful marketing practices and the payment of kickbacks aimed at promoting sales of its surgical preparation solution, Chloraprep. Also involved in the settlement was the federal government, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-carefusion-corp
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20181013211828/https://ag.ny.gov/press-release/ag-schneiderman-announces-40m-settlement-resolving-fraud-allegations-against-health

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: C.R. Bard, Inc. and its parent company Becton, Dickinson and Company agreed to pay $60 million to 48 states and the District of Columbia to resolve allegations that C.R. Bard deceptively marketed its transvaginal surgical mesh devices.
Info Source: https://www.azag.gov/press-release/cr-bard-and-becton-dickinson-and-company-pay-115-million-arizona-pelvic-mesh-device
